Completing the MOD

Building Your MOD:

The MOD SDK installer creates a .bat file in the root of your install directory.  To build your MOD simply run this from a command prompt and pass it one parameter which is the name of your MOD.  You can test this on the Sample MOD by running BuildMOD.bat SampleMOD from the command line:

        Installation Folder:\> BuildMOD.bat SampleMOD 

Windows Vista Only: 
The Buildmod.bat file must be run from an elevated (one with Administrator privileges) command prompt, which can be done by using Run as Administrator when starting cmd.

This will create and generate a .big file for you.  Once you’ve successfully built your MOD the big file for your MOD will be located in the BuiltMods\MODs folder.  In the case of the Sample MOD this will be sampleMOD.big.  The .bat file will also automatically copy this file to the My Documents\Command & Conquer 3 Tiberium Wars\mods\<mod name> folder.  This is where your completed MODs should be placed to be run in the game.  The only step left to getting your MOD to appear in the game is the creation of a Skudef file which is covered in the next section of this document.

Building a Custom Map:

If you have created a map that uses assets from your new MOD you will need to build this map before you build the MOD so that it is properly packed into your new big file.  We have supplied a batch file to do this for you.  Simply run the BuildMap.bat from the root of the MOD SDK install directory passing it two parameters, the name of your MOD and the name of your map.  For example:

BuildMap.bat SampleMOD SampleMap

Windows Vista Only: 
The Buildmap.bat file must be run from an elevated (one with Administrator privileges) command prompt, which can be done by using Run as Administrator when starting cmd.

This file will copy your map file from the default save location to your MODs folder than process it with the Binary Asset Builder which will place the compiled files into your BuiltMODs directory.  After doing this step you can build your MOD using BuildMOD.bat as indicated in the section above.

Creating a SkuDef File:

The creation of the SkuDef file is the final step in getting your MOD to appear in the game.  The name of the SkuDef file is very important.  It should follow this format:

<modname>_<modversion>.SkuDef

The SampleMOD SkuDef is named: SampleMOD_1.0.SkuDef.

The SkuDef is just a text file that tells the game about your big file.  Here is what the Sample MOD SkuDef file looks like on the inside:

mod-game 1.7
add-big samplemod.big

The first line tells the game what version of the game this MOD runs with.  The second line just tells the game about your big file.  The SkuDef file should be located in the same directory as your .big file in the My Documents folder listed in the previous section.

Please note that the maximum length your mod name can be is 15 characters.

Launching Your MOD in Game:

Launch the Command & Conquer 3 Tiberium Wars™ Control Center from the Start Menu, then click on the Game Launcher button.  You will now be presented with a screen with two tabs Replays and MODs.  Select the MODs folder if it has not already been selected.  Find your MOD in the list, and click on the launch button.  That’s it!  You should now be checking out your MOD in-game.
